text: The Transactivation Functions of HTLV-I <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Are Suppressed by <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1>

Previous studies by Bettelli and colleagues have demonstrated that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can repress both the basal levels of NF-kappaB activation as well as <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - stimulated NF-kappaB activation [ 15 ] .
Our next step was to determine whether <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> could also suppress the activation of NF-kappaB caused by a strong viral transactivator protein .
HTLV-I encodes a multifunctional transactivator protein , <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , capable of activating both the NF-kappaB and CREB pathways [ 24-29 ] .

Since the HTLV-I <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein can function at multiple levels in both the cytoplasm and the nucleus to stimulate activation of NF-kappaB [ 28 , 29 ] , we hypothesized that overexpression of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may interfere with this process .

However , since <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent HTLV-I gene expression is independent of NF-kappaB [ 18 ] , we also hypothesized that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> would not affect <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent activation of the HTLV-I LTR .

To test these hypotheses , we overexpressed HTLV-I <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , full-length <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and / or <extra_id_0> DeltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in HEK 293T cells cotransfected with an HTLV-I LTR or NF-kappaB reporter vector .

text: As shown in Figure 4A , HTLV-I <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> strongly up-regulated NF-kappaB - dependent transcriptional activation ( ~60-fold ) .

Interestingly , overexpression of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not <extra_id_0> DeltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , suppressed <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated activation of NF-kappaB - dependent transcription .

text: These observations further suggest that the carboxyl-terminal FKH domain is required for inhibiting activation of NF-kappaB in the presence of <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in HEK 293T cells , strikingly similar to the requirements of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibition of basal NF-kappaB activation shown in Figure 2B .

Transactivation of the HTLV-I LTR was stimulated about 55-fold by overexpression of <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Figure 4B ) , while transfection of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> suppressed <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent HTLV-I LTR activation , although HTLV-I LTR activation in the presence or absence of <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is independent of NF-kappaB or NF-AT ( another transcriptional activator known to interact with <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

text: Furthermore , overexpression of <extra_id_0> DeltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also led to suppression of HTLV-I transactivation by <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to a similar extent as full-length <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Figure 4B ) .

The suppressive effects shown in Figure 4A and 4B were not the result of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> down-regulating the expression of the transfected <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> plasmid as determined by real-time RT-PCR ( Figure 4C ) .

text: These results strongly suggest that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interacts with transcriptional regulators in addition to NF-kappaB and NF-AT , and that the carboxyl-terminal FKH domain , and therefore localization to the nucleus , are not required for inhibition of <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated HTLV-I LTR activation ( even in HEK 293T cells ) .

text: To determine whether <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibited the transactivation functions of <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by directly associating with this viral protein , we generated an expression vector in which HTLV-I <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was fused in-frame to the carboxyl terminus of the <extra_id_0> Gal4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> DNA - binding domain ( <extra_id_0> Gal4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - BD ) .

text: This <extra_id_0> Gal4-BD-Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> fusion protein activated transcription of a synthetic promoter containing five Gal4 binding sites , while <extra_id_0> Gal4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - BD was insufficient to stimulate transcription by itself ( Figure 4D ) .

Transactivation of the Gal4-resposive promoter by <extra_id_0> Gal4-BD-Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> remained relatively unaffected by overexpression of either EGFP ( control ) , <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , or <extra_id_0> DeltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , suggesting that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> does not repress <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transactivation by directly interfacing with the HTLV-I <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein .

text: To confirm that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> had a direct effect on HTLV-I replication , we transfected HEK 293T cells with a well-characterized HTLV-I infectious molecular clone ( termed ACH ) [ 30 ] in the presence of full-length <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> DeltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , or control vector .

ACH has been previously shown to direct the expression of viral antigens , produce infectious virus , and transform <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells both in vitro and in vivo [ 31 , 32 ] .
After 24 h , the amount of viral antigen expression , in this case <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA , was detected by a sensitive real-time RT-PCR assay .

As illustrated in Figure 5 , the level of <extra_id_0> Tax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA synthesized from ACH was down-regulated in the presence of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> compared to the level produced in the presence of the control vector .
